text: I made 28 return on my money in less than two months on this trade, but I could have made more. I want to walk you through the Apple ratio call diagonal. I brought up on some of the YouTube live sessions. And I want to share with you at the end of the video some different scenarios that could have played out if I placed the trade differently and talk about how I think about those because it's really important to keep things in context. What's up everybody? Eric here. Welcome back to all the outliers. Shout out to the Patreon family if my videos are useful to you consider signing up. It helps me out a bunch. Let's get right into the video. Okay, so here we have a trade in Apple. And essentially I entered here with some 190 days to expiration, deep in the money long calls. And I also sold some short premium against them. The reason why I like this trade is because it allows me to benefit from the leverage of options, but then also collect some premium upfront. So that's exactly what I'm doing. It's also known as a poor man's covered call, which is slightly different than what I'm doing here. It's a ratio diagonal. Now as I progress through the trade, I started noticing that there is definitely some bullish bias here. I was getting the movements that I wanted to see. And I needed to make some interesting adjustments

I went from a two lot to a one lot because I was seeing that bullish confirmation. I wanted to let it move to the upside. And that's exactly why I wanted to reduce some of the short deltas against the longs. Give it some more room to run. And then the rest of the short calls that I was using in this instance, I kept it down at that two to one ratio. The reason why I had a one to one when I first entered is because the deltas were offset enough that I still had upside potential to run. Now, I did end up having a bunch of these that I close for losses throughout the cycle of the trade. And again, that's because I was favoring the upside potential as compared to salvaging the credit that I could collect on the trade. So you can look through this, see what you think. And the ultimate end state here is I exited. I didn't exit both leaps at the same time. I exited one of them to cover the cost of this in the money short call that I couldn't wiggle out of. text: want it to make, you don't have to fight it all of the way. Now one of the things somebody was asking me is how did I kind of decide when to take profits? Like why didn't I exit here or why didn't I exit here? The main reason is is I'm following the trend. As long as the trend continues to move where I want it to move, what I like to do is continually slide up my stops. So what I mean by that is if I grab this price level and I show you my original stop was, you know, like I said somewhere right around here around 162. And that's when it was on the 10th of May. Then when I saw it rally up here into this like one high 170s, I slid my stop up to here to 170. Then as I saw it start to catch this leg, I look for the next set of near term resistance, which I considered something around here, maybe like 181. And I'm just using the tops from here and then the bottoms from here. And then I'm using the moving averages as my shorter term indicator as I'm sliding this thing up. I care about the slope and I care about the organization. So as long as it continues following the trend, then I'm going to try to stay in it. If I didn't have the short calls expiring that forced my hand to close here,
